column1: Our ears are complex anatomical structures that are separated into three main parts
column4: and inner ear. The outer ear is the only visible part of the ear and is primarily used for funneling sound from the environment into the ear canal. From there
column5: sound travels into the middle ear
column6: where it vibrates the eardrum and three tiny bones
column8: that transmit sound energy to the inner ear. The energy continues to travel to the inner ear
column9: where it is received by the cochlea. The cochlea is a structure within the ear that is shaped like a snail shell
column10: and it contains the Organ of Corti
column11: where sensory "hair cells" are present that can sense the sound energy. When the cochlea receives the sound
column12: it amplifies the signal detected by these hair cells and transmits the signal through the auditory nerve to the brain. While the ears are responsible for receiving sound from the environment
column13: it is the brain that perceives and makes sense of these sounds. The auditory cortex of the brain is located within a region called the temporal lobe and is specialized for processing and interpreting sounds.
